The role of the Laplace transformation defined by \\( \\mathcal{L}(z)(s) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st}z(t) dt \\) on this system is analyzed.

If an additional term \\( h(t) = e^{\\alpha t} \\) where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant, is introduced into the system at time \\( t = 0 \\) and the system is then observed over time, will \\( \\mathcal{L}(z)(s) \\) for s in the complex plane remain the same as without the intervention?
Explanation: The introduction of \\( h(t) \\) modifies the original system by changing the form of the differential equation, effectively altering the solution z(t). This change will be reflected in the Laplace transform, resulting in a different expression than if \\( h(t) \\) had not been introduced. \\( h(t) = e^{\\alpha t} \\) transforms into \\( \\frac{1}{s-\\alpha} \\) in the s-domain, altering the resulting system equation.
